title: Graph of a function based on its derivative

content.question: If <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>|</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <mo>|</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math> which of the following could be the graph of <math> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math>?

choices.label: A graph plots a v shaped curve the originates in the second quadrant, falls through the point 0 comma 2 to the point 2 comma 0, and further rises through the point 4 comma 2 into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

A graph plots a u shaped curve the originates in the second quadrant, falls through the point 0 comma 2 to the point 2 comma 0, and further rises through the point 4 comma 2 into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve that originates in the second quadrant, falls down to the origin, rises to the point 2 comma 2 and falls down to the point 4 comma 0, and further rises into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

A graph plots two curves. The first curve is a concave rightward curve that originates in the third quadrant, passes through the origin into the first quadrant. The second curve is a concave leftward curve that originates in the fourth quadrant, passes through the point 4 comma 0 into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

A graph plots a curve the originates in the fourth quadrant, rises through the point 0 comma negative 2 into the fourth quadrant, bends at the point 2 comma 0 and further rises into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

content.answer: A graph plots a curve the originates in the fourth quadrant, rises through the point 0 comma negative 2 into the fourth quadrant, bends at the point 2 comma 0 and further rises into the first quadrant. All values estimated.

topic.text: 5.8: Sketching Graphs of Functions and Their Derivatives

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
